canonical_explanation.text: When two lines intersect, they form pairs of vertically opposite angles (which are equal) and linear pairs (which are supplementary). When a transversal intersects two parallel lines, it creates pairs of corresponding angles (equal), alternate interior angles (equal), and co-interior angles (supplementary). The angle sum property states that the sum of all angles in a triangle is 180°. The exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.
rules: Linear pair: two adjacent angles on a straight line sum to 180°
Corresponding angles are equal when a transversal cuts parallel lines
Alternate interior angles are equal when a transversal cuts parallel lines
Co-interior (same-side interior) angles are supplementary when a transversal cuts parallel lines
Exterior angle = sum of two opposite interior angles

questions.question_text: If two angles form a linear pair and one angle is 70°, the other angle is:
questions.explanation_correct: A linear pair sums to 180°. So the other angle = 180° − 70° = 110°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Linear pair angles are supplementary (sum = 180°). The other angle = 180° − 70° = 110°.

questions.question_text: Vertically opposite angles are:
questions.explanation_correct: When two lines intersect, the vertically opposite angles (angles across from each other) are always equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vertically opposite angles are equal. This is a theorem that follows from the linear pair axiom.

questions.question_text: Two supplementary angles always add up to 180°.
questions.explanation_correct: By definition, supplementary angles are two angles whose measures add up to 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Supplementary angles sum to 180° by definition. Complementary angles sum to 90°.

questions.question_text: Two complementary angles sum to:
questions.explanation_correct: By definition, two complementary angles add up to 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary angles sum to 90°. Supplementary angles sum to 180°.

questions.question_text: If two lines intersect and one of the angles is 45°, then the vertically opposite angle is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: Vertically opposite angles are equal. If one is 45°, the one opposite to it is also 45°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vertically opposite angles are always equal, so the opposite angle is also 45°.

questions.question_text: When a transversal intersects two parallel lines, corresponding angles are:
questions.explanation_correct: When a transversal cuts two parallel lines, each pair of corresponding angles is equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corresponding angles formed by a transversal and parallel lines are equal, not supplementary.

questions.question_text: Alternate interior angles formed by a transversal cutting two parallel lines are:
questions.explanation_correct: Alternate interior angles are equal when the transversal intersects parallel lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alternate interior angles between parallel lines are always equal.

questions.question_text: Co-interior angles (same-side interior angles) between parallel lines are:
questions.explanation_correct: Co-interior angles (also called consecutive interior angles or same-side interior angles) are supplementary when formed between parallel lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Co-interior angles between parallel lines always add up to 180°.

questions.question_text: The sum of the three angles of a triangle is:
questions.explanation_correct: The angle sum property of a triangle states that the sum of all three interior angles is always 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle sum of a triangle is always 180°, regardless of the type of triangle.

questions.question_text: An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to:

options.text: The sum of all three interior angles
The sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles

questions.explanation_correct: The exterior angle theorem: an exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of the two interior opposite (non-adjacent) angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An exterior angle equals the sum of the two remote (non-adjacent) interior angles, not all three.

questions.question_text: If two adjacent angles form a linear pair, they are always supplementary.
questions.explanation_correct: The linear pair axiom states that if a ray stands on a line, the two adjacent angles formed are supplementary (sum = 180°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, a linear pair consists of two adjacent angles on a straight line that sum to 180°.

questions.question_text: In a triangle, if two angles are 60° and 70°, the third angle is ___°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By the angle sum property: 60° + 70° + third angle = 180°, so third angle = 50°.

questions.question_text: Two lines intersect at point O forming angles. If one angle is 130°, the adjacent angle is:
questions.explanation_correct: Adjacent angles at the point of intersection are supplementary (linear pair). So 180° − 130° = 50°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An adjacent angle forms a linear pair and must sum to 180°. So 180° − 130° = 50°.

questions.question_text: If corresponding angles are equal when a transversal cuts two lines, then the two lines are:
questions.explanation_correct: The converse of the corresponding angles theorem: if corresponding angles are equal, the lines are parallel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal corresponding angles is both a consequence and a proof of parallel lines (theorem and its converse).

questions.question_text: An exterior angle of a triangle is 120° and one of the interior opposite angles is 50°. The other interior opposite angle is:
questions.explanation_correct: Exterior angle = sum of two interior opposite angles. So 120° = 50° + x, giving x = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By the exterior angle theorem: other angle = 120° − 50° = 70°.

questions.question_text: Two lines intersect. If one of the four angles formed is 65°, find the other three angles:
questions.explanation_correct: Vertically opposite = 65°. The two adjacent angles = 180° − 65° = 115° each. So: 65°, 115°, 115°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At the intersection, opposite angles are equal (65°) and adjacent angles are supplementary (115°). The other three are 65°, 115°, 115°.

questions.question_text: A transversal intersects two parallel lines. If one of the corresponding angles is 55°, find the co-interior angle on the same side:
questions.explanation_correct: The corresponding angle is 55°. The co-interior angle on the same side is supplementary to the alternate interior angle. Co-interior = 180° − 55° = 125°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Co-interior angles are supplementary. If one angle at the intersection is 55°, the co-interior angle = 180° − 55° = 125°.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, angle A = 45° and angle B = 65°. Find angle C:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using angle sum property: A + B + C = 180°, so C = 180° − 45° − 65° = 70°.

questions.question_text: In a triangle, the angles are in the ratio 2:3:4. What is the largest angle?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of ratios = 2+3+4 = 9. Each part = 180°/9 = 20°. The largest angle = 4 × 20° = 80°.

questions.question_text: If a transversal intersects two parallel lines and the alternate interior angles are (2x + 10)° and (3x − 20)°, then x = ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Alternate interior angles are equal: 2x + 10 = 3x − 20. Solving: 10 + 20 = 3x − 2x, so x = 30.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since alternate interior angles between parallel lines are equal: 2x + 10 = 3x − 20, giving x = 30.

questions.question_text: If two angles of a linear pair are (3x + 10)° and (2x + 20)°, find x:
Lines l and m are parallel. A transversal makes an angle of 72° with line l. What angle does it make with line m on the same side?
questions.explanation_correct: The transversal can make a corresponding angle of 72° or a co-interior angle of 108° with line m, depending on which angle is being considered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Depending on position: corresponding angle = 72° (same side, same position) or co-interior angle = 180° − 72° = 108°.

questions.question_text: A triangle can have two right angles.
questions.explanation_correct: If two angles are 90° each, their sum is 180°. The third angle would be 0°, which is impossible. So a triangle cannot have two right angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two right angles = 180°, leaving 0° for the third angle. This is impossible, so a triangle can have at most one right angle.

questions.question_text: The sides of a triangle are extended to form exterior angles. The sum of all three exterior angles is:
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of exterior angles (one at each vertex) of any convex polygon is 360°. For a triangle: each exterior angle = 180° − interior angle. Sum = 3(180°) − 180° = 360°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of three exterior angles = 540° − 180° = 360° (since each exterior + interior = 180°, and interior sum = 180°).

questions.question_text: In the figure, AB ∥ CD and a transversal EF intersects them. If angle AEF = 40°, find angle EFD (co-interior angle):
questions.explanation_correct: Co-interior angles are supplementary. Angle EFD = 180° − 40° = 140°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since AB ∥ CD, co-interior angles sum to 180°. So angle EFD = 180° − 40° = 140°.

questions.question_text: One angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the other two. What type of triangle is it?
questions.explanation_correct: Let the angle = sum of other two. Since all three sum to 180°, the angle = 180°/2 = 90°. It is a right triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If A = B + C and A + B + C = 180°, then 2A = 180°, so A = 90°. The triangle is right-angled.

questions.question_text: Two angles are supplementary. If one is 5 times the other, the smaller angle is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: Let smaller angle = x. Then 5x + x = 180°, so 6x = 180°, x = 30°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If one angle is x and the other is 5x, then x + 5x = 180° → 6x = 180° → x = 30°.

questions.question_text: In triangle PQR, angle P = 50° and angle Q = 70°. The exterior angle at R is:
questions.explanation_correct: Exterior angle at R = angle P + angle Q = 50° + 70° = 120°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By exterior angle theorem: exterior angle at R = sum of two remote interior angles = 50° + 70° = 120°.

questions.question_text: If two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, how many pairs of alternate interior angles are formed?
questions.explanation_correct: When a transversal intersects two parallel lines, 2 pairs of alternate interior angles are formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A transversal creates 8 angles total at two intersection points, with 2 pairs of alternate interior angles.

questions.question_text: An equilateral triangle has all angles equal to 60°.
questions.explanation_correct: In an equilateral triangle, all sides are equal, so all angles are equal. Since they sum to 180°, each = 180°/3 = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three angles are equal and sum to 180°, so each must be 60°.

questions.question_text: In the figure, lines PQ and RS intersect at O. If angle POR = 3x and angle QOS = 2x + 30°, find x:
questions.explanation_correct: Angles POR and QOS are vertically opposite, so they're equal: 3x = 2x + 30, giving x = 30.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vertically opposite angles are equal: 3x = 2x + 30 → x = 30.

questions.question_text: In the figure, AB ∥ CD. The transversal PQ makes angle APQ = 50° and angle PQD = 130°. Is AB ∥ CD justified?

options.text: Yes, because corresponding angles are equal
Yes, because co-interior angles are supplementary (50° + 130° = 180°)
No, the angles should be equal

questions.explanation_correct: Co-interior angles sum to 50° + 130° = 180°. Since co-interior angles are supplementary, AB ∥ CD is confirmed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The co-interior angles sum to 180°. This is the condition for parallel lines, confirming AB ∥ CD.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, if angle A = 2x, angle B = 3x, and angle C = 4x, find all three angles:
An exterior angle of a triangle is 110°. If the two non-adjacent interior angles are equal, each of them is:
questions.explanation_correct: Exterior angle = sum of two non-adjacent interior angles. If equal: 2x = 110°, x = 55°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If both remote interior angles are x, then 2x = 110°, so x = 55° each.

questions.question_text: AB ∥ CD and EF is a transversal. If angle AEF = 70° and angle EFC = (2x + 10)°, find x:
questions.explanation_correct: Angle AEF and angle EFC are co-interior angles. Sum = 180°: 70 + (2x+10) = 180. 2x + 80 = 180. 2x = 100. x = 50.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Co-interior angles: 70 + 2x + 10 = 180 → 2x = 100 → x = 50.

questions.question_text: Three lines meet at a point, forming 6 angles. If one angle is 40° and the angle adjacent to it is 90°, the angle adjacent to the 90° angle (on the other side) is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: Three lines at a point create 6 angles summing to 360°. Opposite angles are equal. 40° + 90° + x = 180° (on one side), so x = 50°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The three angles on one side of a line through the point sum to 180°: 40° + 90° + x = 180°, so x = 50°.

questions.question_text: In a right-angled triangle, if one acute angle is 35°, the other acute angle is:
questions.explanation_correct: One angle = 90°, another = 35°. Third = 180° − 90° − 35° = 55°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of angles: 90° + 35° + third = 180°, so third = 55°.

questions.question_text: AB ∥ CD. A transversal intersects AB at P and CD at Q. If angle APQ = 65° and angle CQP = 65°, which pair are these angles?
questions.explanation_correct: Angle APQ and angle CQP are on opposite sides of the transversal and between the parallel lines. They are alternate interior angles, and being equal confirms AB ∥ CD.
questions.explanation_incorrect: These angles are between the parallel lines on alternate sides of the transversal, making them alternate interior angles.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, side BC is produced to D. If angle ACD = 115° and angle A = 45°, find angle B:
questions.explanation_correct: Exterior angle ACD = angle A + angle B. So 115° = 45° + angle B, giving angle B = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By exterior angle theorem: angle B = exterior angle − angle A = 115° − 45° = 70°.

questions.question_text: If two lines are perpendicular, the vertically opposite angles at their intersection are each 90°.
questions.explanation_correct: Perpendicular lines intersect at 90°. All four angles are 90° (each pair of vertically opposite angles is 90°, and each linear pair sums to 180°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: When perpendicular lines meet, one angle is 90°, its vertically opposite angle is 90°, and the other two are also 90° each.

questions.question_text: Two lines are cut by a transversal such that a pair of alternate interior angles are 55° and 60°. Are the lines parallel?

options.text: Yes, because 55° and 60° are nearly equal
No, because alternate interior angles must be equal for parallel lines
Yes, because their sum is less than 180°

questions.explanation_correct: For lines to be parallel, alternate interior angles must be exactly equal. Since 55° ≠ 60°, the lines are not parallel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parallel lines require equal alternate interior angles. 55° ≠ 60° means the lines are not parallel.

questions.question_text: Can a triangle have angles 60°, 80°, and 50°?

options.text: Yes, all angles are less than 180°
No, because the angles are all different

questions.explanation_correct: 60° + 80° + 50° = 190° ≠ 180°. Since the angle sum property requires 180°, this triangle is not possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sum 190° > 180° violates the angle sum property. No triangle can have these three angles.

questions.question_text: If AB ∥ CD and a transversal makes angle 48° with AB, the corresponding angle at CD is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: Corresponding angles between parallel lines are equal. So the corresponding angle at CD is also 48°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corresponding angles are equal when lines are parallel. The angle at CD = 48°.

questions.question_text: In a triangle, the interior angles are (x + 10)°, (2x − 30)°, and (x + 20)°. Find the value of the exterior angle at the vertex with angle (x + 10)°:
questions.explanation_correct: (x+10) + (2x−30) + (x+20) = 180 → 4x = 180 → x = 45. Interior angle at that vertex = 45+10 = 55°. Exterior angle = 180° − 55° = 125°. Or equivalently, exterior angle = sum of other two interior angles = 60° + 65° = 125°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find x: 4x = 180, x = 45. The angle at that vertex = 55°. Exterior angle = 180° − 55° = 125°.

questions.question_text: Two angles are in the ratio 3:7 and form a linear pair. Find the angles:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Linear pair sums to 180°: 10x = 180°, x = 18°. Angles are 3(18) = 54° and 7(18) = 126°.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, angle bisectors of angles B and C meet at point I. If angle A = 80°, find angle BIC:
questions.explanation_correct: Angle BIC = 90° + A/2 = 90° + 40° = 130°. (This is a standard result for the incenter angle.)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula: angle BIC = 90° + (angle A)/2 = 90° + 80°/2 = 90° + 40° = 130°.

questions.question_text: If a transversal is perpendicular to one of two parallel lines, it is also perpendicular to the other.
questions.explanation_correct: If the transversal makes 90° with one parallel line, the corresponding angle at the other line is also 90° (corresponding angles are equal). So it is perpendicular to both.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corresponding angles between parallel lines are equal. If one is 90°, the other must also be 90°.

questions.question_text: The exterior angles of a triangle are (4x)°, (5x + 20)°, and (6x − 20)°. Find x:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sum of exterior angles of any triangle is 360°. So 15x = 360, giving x = 24.

questions.question_text: If the bisectors of two angles of a linear pair meet, the angle between them is:
questions.explanation_correct: If two angles form a linear pair (sum = 180°), their bisectors make angles half of each. The angle between bisectors = half of 180° = 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the linear pair angles are a and b where a + b = 180°, the bisectors make a/2 and b/2 with the common arm. Angle between bisectors = a/2 + b/2 = 90°.

questions.question_text: The angles of a triangle are (x−40)°, (x−20)°, and (x/2−10)°. The value of x is ___.
